Do flies on the gossamer's thread</br>Dance wanton the stubble among?</br>Or larks to the lap of the mead</br>Descend to encircle their young?</br>So, Delia, the muse of my breast</br>Thy delicate graces enjoin,</br>Thy bosom pavilions her nest,</br>Of joy thy acceptance her line.

Does Delia, more soft than the down,</br>That velvets the willow in spring,</br>My simile see with a frown?</br>Or smile as I venture to sing?</br>The gales from the mountain's green tops</br>When vermils the finger of morn,</br>The summer replenish'd with crops,</br>The pearl pending bright from the thorn.

Nor health, with her blue-brighten'd eye,</br>More jocund appears in the vale,</br>More placid the tints of the sky,</br>When breathes with ambrosia the gale;</br>Not virtue more sweetly divine,</br>When healing the wounds of despair,</br>As when with her dimples benign</br>She robs my fond heart of its care.

To virtue transcendent allied,</br>Now bless'd in her smiles are the hills;</br>How tranquil steals forward the tide?</br>How soft is the fall of the rills?</br>The serpentine path edg'd with flow'rs,</br>The nymphs and the shepherds explore,</br>Gay frolick purloins from the hours,</br>And sorrow and winter's no more.

The guileless are festive alone</br>The fair by pure innocence sway'd,</br>Shall beam from festivity's throne,</br>All hail thou beneficent maid;</br>That joy that hymns peace to the mind,</br>With whispers so silvery sweet,</br>Those warblings that issue refin'd,</br>When loves on the graces await,

Are thine, gentle Delia, and thine</br>The rubies that warm'd Helen's cheek,</br>Whose bosom not half so divine,</br>Comparison faulters to speak:</br>The ring-dove that perch'd on the oak</br>In verdure no longer array'd,</br>Permit that my muse may invoke</br>In emblem as pure as the maid.

A willow that bent o'er the brook,</br>Was wont a green seat to afford;</br>What magic on nature to look!</br>Or nature to summer restor'd!</br>Then Delia was close to my side</br>Loves paradise beam'd from her mind;</br>"Creation's vermillion, I cried,</br>December without thee I find.

"Thou chaste as Lucretia in thought,</br>Without thee would madrigals yield,</br>That music with harmony fraught,</br>That undulates thorough the field:</br>Accept my oblation, I cried;</br>My passions record and approve;"</br>My eyes in that moment espied</br>The hectic of importun'd love.

The tender emotion I trac'd,</br>'Twas long since her blushes I caus'd;</br>The planets revolving have chac'd</br>Three moons since her Corydon paus'd,</br>Then climb'd to the steep of the hill,</br>Collecting a posy of sweets;</br>The iris and slender-leav'd dill</br>I tore from their grassy retreats.

Must absence then harrow my breast?</br>Ah why should its sorrows prevail?</br>The cherub of sweetness confess'd</br>'Tis winter confines to the dale:</br>When Corydon visits her cot,</br>Not beauty that rays from her eye,</br>But virtues that fall to her lot,</br>With graces that flourish hard by.

'Tis those welcome guests that my muse,</br>Though barren of elegant rhyme,</br>With energy wishes infuse</br>In measure to steal upon time:</br>O come then sweet goddess, content,</br>O come to tranquility's bower,</br>Upon thy calm comforts intent</br>I wooe thee to smile on the hour.

For cherish'd by thee, on the plain</br>The hawthorn in solitude blows;</br>The muse shall each essay explain</br>As fancy from sentiment flows:</br>So bright fair content is thy form,</br>Fair daughter of virtue most pure;</br>'Tis Delia and thee that must warm,</br>The pleasures of life to endure.

With folly the mind undebas'd,</br>Feels all that thy pleasures can pour;</br>Thy walk to the closure I trac'd,</br>And look'd with delight on thy store;</br>Ambition, that's false as 'tis mean,</br>The pomp of the wickedly great;</br>Content in thy converse not seen,</br>Nor seen in the cottager's seat.

To courts from retirement exil'd,</br>From streams which soft murmur along,</br>Ambition and pomp how beguil'd!</br>Contentment they hear not thy song:</br>Thy theme of unlimited joy</br>I hear from the lips of the vale;</br>Let luxury rise to destroy,</br>And splendour paint pageantry's sail.

The tempest of vice I defy,</br>The thunders of rapine may roll,</br>Relentless its whirlwinds may fly,</br>And conscience retort on the soul:</br>Content her protection shall yield,</br>Stretch over the cottage her wing,</br>Ambitious my Delia to shield,</br>Nor scorn whom her praises shall sing.</br>
